summary: This is an email chain from July 24, 2019, between law enforcement personnel on the FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force. The email discusses efforts to locate and interview former employees of Jeffrey Epstein who worked at his New York home during the period when abuse was occurring. The sender attaches background reports on one employee and requests assistance with conducting interviews.

persons.name: Detective NYPD FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force
persons.context: The sender of the email, who is coordinating the effort to locate and interview former Epstein employees as part of the investigation into abuse at Epstein's New York home.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the investigation; the email discusses interviewing his former employees about abuse occurring in his New York home.

persons.name: Wexner
persons.context: Mentioned as the previous owner of the New York address where Epstein later lived.

connections.person2: Detective NYPD FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force
connections.description: The detective is investigating Epstein for alleged abuse occurring in his New York home.
Epstein lived at a New York address previously owned by Wexner.

events.title: Email coordination for employee interviews
events.description: Law enforcement coordinates via email to locate and interview former Epstein employees about abuse at his New York home.
personsInvolved: Detective NYPD FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force

keyFacts: Law enforcement was actively seeking to interview former employees of Jeffrey Epstein in July 2019 as part of the investigation into abuse at his New York home.
One former employee was identified as approximately 80 years old and had been living in Nassau County since 2000.
The investigation focused on the employee's knowledge of Epstein, a massage room, and the comings and goings of girls at the New York residence.
The New York property where Epstein lived was previously owned by Wexner.
Prosecutors (AUSAs) were actively following up with law enforcement to complete these employee interviews.
